    <div id="item-header" class="item item-header">
<div class="block block-red">
  <h1 class="logo main-logo title textbar textbar-big">Coding</h1>
  <br>
  <h1 class="logo main-logo title textbar textbar-big">The</h1>
  <br>
  <h1 class="logo main-logo title textbar textbar-big">Humanities</h1>
  <div><p>Universities are wasting resources – teachers teach and students study. The knowledge of students isn’t leveraged and their learning isn’t shared. Most people still see a classroom as one teacher and a group of students. Coding the Humanities sees a classroom as a group of potential teachers. While degrees become more and more expensive, Coding the Humanities builds a set of teaching practices and tools that make education accessible, shared and usable again.</p>

    </div>

    </div>

    </div>

    <div id=“item-body-2” class=“item item-body item-num-2”>

    <div class="column-left">
  <div class="block block-yellow">
<h1 class="textbar title">From Content to Context</h1>
<div><p>Everybody possesses a piece of knowledge or a skill that is worthy to share with others, but in traditional education, what students know is left out.</p>

    </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-aquamarine">
<h2>The Alternative Classroom</h2>
<div><p>Imagine two classrooms. In the first, you see a teacher who teaches a group of students. The students’ knowledge is wasted. In the second classroom, you see a group of people who share what they know. They are teaching each other. Yet, traditional education – and many online learning solutions – are still modelled after the first classroom.</p>

    <p>While the educational system is wasting most of its in-house knowledge, degrees become more and more expensive.</p> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-orange">
<h2>Be Lazy, Impatient and Bold</h2>
<div><p>In May 2013, Coding the Humanities created its first alternative classroom to create an environment to involve students in their own teaching practice. Students were encouraged to be:</p>

    <ul>

    <li>Lazy and steal the work of others</li>
<li>Impatient and make something before you know something</li>
<li>Bold and share every step they take</li>

    </ul>

    <p>Knowledge can come from everywhere, but as it turned out, most knowledge came from Google. Students found everything they needed to know in each other or the internet. There was no need for content. There was a need to organize what they found.</p> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      </div>
  <div class="column-right">
    <div class="block block-grey">
<h2></h2>
<div>

    </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
  <div class="reference-line"></div>
  <h3>Activities:</h3>
    <div class="reference">

  <p>art-science-and-technology-i</p>
  <p></p>
</a>

    </div>

  <p></p>
</a>

    </div>

    <div class="reference">

  <p></p>
</a>

    </div>

    </div>

    </div>

    </div>

    </div> <div id=“item-body-3” class=“item item-body item-num-3”>

    <div class="column-left">
  <div class="block block-yellow">
<h1 class="textbar title">From Context to Curation</h1>
<div><p>Today, almost anything you want to learn is accessible online. Creating new online learning materials is a waste of time – use what’s already there instead.</p>

    </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-aquamarine">
<h2>Steal + Make + Share = Curate</h2>
<div><p>Back in the days, if you wanted to study linguistics from Umberto Eco, you’d have to travel to Bologna. Today, people can do this from behind their computer.</p>

    <p>Almost anything people would want to learn exists online somewhere. Creating new materials for teaching is a waste of time. Instead:</p>

    <ul>

    <li>Steal what’s already there</li>
<li>Make meaningful packets of knowledge</li>
<li>Share them with someone who wants to learn</li>

    </ul> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-orange">
<h2>Learn, Teach, Repeat</h2>
<div><p>From Coding the Humanities emerged the need for a tool that would support this type of content curation for learning. The students developed a paper prototype of a tool that helped them structure series of learning resources in meaningful paths.</p>

    <p>The tool leverages people’s knowledge. And better yet, it allows people to focus on a topic that is specific and personal to them. The tool encourages the student to share their collections – to have them teach others and be taught something in return.</p>

    <p>Creating a collection is a learning process. Sharing your collection with someone else is teaching. On the platform, students go back and forth: they learn, they teach and repeat. The teacher becomes a facilitator.</p> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      </div>
  <div class="column-right">
    <div class="block block-grey">
<h2></h2>
<div>

    </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
  <div class="reference-line"></div>
  <h3>Activities:</h3>

  <p></p>
</a>

    </div>

    </div>

    </div> <div id=“item-body-4” class=“item item-body item-num-4”>

    <div class="column-left">
  <div class="block block-yellow">
<h1 class="textbar title">From Curation to Facilitation</h1>
<div><p>There are many tools for curation or teaching. Coding the Humanities builds a tool that teaches through curation.</p>

    </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-aquamarine">
<h2>Different Tools for Different Means</h2>
<div><p>Students use all kinds of different tools to store resources. Teachers use all kinds of different tools to share resources. Almost none of these tools are designed to facilitate the learning process. In the autumn of 2015, we surveyed and interviewed 9 Coding the Humanities students. The results showed that students:</p>

    <ul>

    <li>Describe learning something as telling a story</li>
<li>Learn best with clear, personal goals in mind</li>
<li>Share little of what they learn and make</li>
<li>Are often unaware of how they learn</li>

    </ul> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      <div class="block block-orange">
<h2>Organise, Track and Share the Learning Process</h2>
<div><p>With the results of earlier prototypes and the research in mind, the current digital space co-designed by Lifely, is an environment that helps students and teachers to organise, track and share learning resources and exercises. The tool facilitates stealing, making in sharing. On the platform you can:</p>

    <ul>

    <li>Create, curate and alter hand-picked collections of resources on a specific topic and create a personal learning trajectory</li>
<li>Gather specific feedback on early drafts of your work and the work of your peers</li>
<li>See what others are doing and have done before you – in your class, in parallel classes and classes of the years before you</li>

    </ul>

    <p>The tool isn’t just a tool. It is the development of a teaching practice that makes education accessible, shared and usable again.</p> </div>

    <div class="reference-container">
</div>

    </div>

      </div>
  <div class="column-right">
    <div class="block block-grey">
<h2></h2>

    <div id=“item-about” class=“item item-about”>

    <div class="column-left">
  <div class="block block-red">
    <h1 class="title textbar">About</h1>
    <div class="block-small-typography"><p>In March 2013, the idea for Coding the Humanities was born in Wassenaar, The Netherlands, during a two-day workshop, organized by NIAS, on public and private initiatives in the Digital Humanities.</p>

    <p>Here, Marijn Koolen and Jan Hein Hoogstad, both assistant professor at the University of Amsterdam at the time, formed their first ideas for Coding the Humanities – a program that would teach humanities students how to code their own tools for doing research, learning from and working with various private partners in the technology and cultural industry.</p>

    <p>This pilot turned into a successful set of BA, MA and staff courses, a set of teaching practices and the development of a prototype of a tool that makes education accessible, shared and usable again by leveraging students’ knowledge, by encouraging students to share what they learn and learn from what other students shared, and by involving students in the creation of (personalized) course curriculums.</p> </div>

      </div>
</div>
